OHIO DISABILITY AND HEALTH LINKAGES PARTNERSHIP: LINKING INDIVIDUALS TO ACHIEVE GREATER EQUITY IN SERVICES - OVERVIEW: THE OHIO DISABILITY AND HEALTH PARTNERSHIP (ODHP) PRESENTS THE OHIO DISABILITY AND HEALTH LINKAGES PARTNERSHIP: LINKING INDIVIDUALS TO ACHIEVE GREATER EQUITY IN SERVICES TO ADDRESS HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES AND ADULTS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS. THE PROJECT AIMS TO ADDRESS SIX STRATEGIES: TO (1) ESTABLISH, EXPAND, AND ENHANCE PARTNERSHIPS; (2) CONDUCT COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENTS AND IDENTIFY ACTION STEPS TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS; (3) ADMINISTER AND EVALUATE A TRAINING FOR HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS ON ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE; (4) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO LINK ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS IN THEIR COMMUNITY; (5) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTIONS AND PSE CHANGES, AND DEVELOP NEEDED RESOURCES AND TOOLS; AND (6) DISSEMINATE KEY FINDINGS AND LESSONS LEARNED.POPULATIONS TO BE SERVED: THIS PROJECT WILL TARGET OHIO ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES AND/OR MOBILITY LIMITATIONS IN CONDUCTING A COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENT, ADMINISTERING AND EVALUATING TRAINING FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS, AND IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS AND CHANGES IN POLICIES, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTS. ODHP WILL IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT THAT WILL LINK AT LEAST 200 ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES TO NEEDED HEALTH AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS IN FRANKLIN COUNTY.KEY PARTNERSHIPS: THERE ARE SEVERAL KEY PARTNERS FOR THIS PROJECT, INCLUDING THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY NISONGER CENTER, THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, THE OHIO COLLEGES OF MEDICINE GOVERNMENT RESOURCE CENTER, THE UNIVERSITY OF CINCINNATI CENTER FOR EXCELLENCE IN DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, THE HEALTHCARE COLLABORATIVE OF GREATER COLUMBUS, THE OHIO ASSOCIATION OF COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS, SPECIAL OLYMPICS OHIO, TH E FRANKLIN COUNTY BOARD OF DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY LEADERSHIP EDUCATION IN NEURODEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, AND THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY CENTER FOR FACULTY ADVANCEMENT, MENTORING, AND ENGAGEMENT. IMPORTANTLY, THE ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO THIS PROJECT, THE DISABILITY HEALTH PARTNERSHIP, IS COMPRISED OF OHIOANS WITH DISABILITIES, FAMILY MEMBERS AND CAREGIVERS OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES, AND DISABILITY STAKEHOLDERS.

IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES THROUGH STATE-BASED PUBLICHEALTH PROGRAMS - THE UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH-DISABILITY AND HEALTH PROGRAM (UDOH-DHP) IS APPLYING FOR A NON-RESEARCH COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT UNDER CDC FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: CDC-RFA-DD21-2103: IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML) AND INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (IDD) THROUGH STATE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS. OF UTAH’S TOTAL POPULATION OF ADULTS, MORE THAN HALF A MILLION HAVE A DISABILITY (22.3%, BRFSS). DESPITE PROGRESS IN THE TREATMENT OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES, SIGNIFICANT DIFFERENCES ARE SEEN BETWEEN THEM AND THOSE WITHOUT DISABILITIES. THEY ARE MORE LIKELY TO ENGAGE IN RISKY HEALTH BEHAVIORS, HAVE POOR PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH, AND HAVE REDUCED ACCESS TO OR USE PREVENTIVE HEALTHCARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION SERVICES. FOR EXAMPLE, IN A STATE KNOWN FOR ITS LOW SMOKING RATES, 17.6% OF UTAH ADULTS WITH A DISABILITY SMOKE COMPARED TO ONLY 6.9% OF ADULTS WITHOUT A DISABILITY. THE UDOH DHP UNDERSTANDS THAT THE REASONS FOR THESE HEALTH DIFFERENCES ARE VARIED, INCLUDING BIOLOGICAL, BUT THAT MUCH OF THE DIFFERENCES WE SEE ARE AVOIDABLE AND SOCIETALLY BASED. DHP RECOGNIZES THAT DISPROPORTIONATE SOCIOECONOMIC DISADVANTAGES, SUCH AS FOOD SECURITY, INCOME, AND EDUCATION, FACED BY PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES IMPACT THEIR ABILITY TO LIVE HEALTHY LIVES OR ACCESS NEEDED SERVICES. POLICIES, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTS (PSE) CAN DISABLE OR ENABLE ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION OPPORTUNITIES. WITH THE CAPACITY THE DHP HAS BUILT OVER THE LAST FIVE YEARS, WITH A STRONG NETWORK OF PARTNERS, THE PROGRAM IS WELL-POSITIONED TO UNDERTAKE THE STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES OUTLINED IN THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY TO HELP ACHIEVE GREATER HEALTH EQUITY AMONG THIS POPULATION. THE EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES OUTLINED WILL DEMONSTRATE INCREASES IN HEALTH-RELATED OUTCOMES AND REDUCTIONS IN HEALTH DISPARITIES IN THE POPULATIONS SERVED BY THE PROGRAM. THE DHP WILL MEASURE SHORT-TERM AND INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES. THE INTERMEDIATE OUTCOM ES ARE AS FOLLOWS: BY JUNE 30, 2026; 1) THE DHP WILL HAVE STRENGTHENED ENGAGEMENT AND COORDINATION WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS AND KEY PARTNERS, AS WELL AS A BROADER REACH AMONG THE TARGET POPULATIONS; 2) THE DHP WILL HAVE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE ABOUT STATE AND JURISDICTIONAL NEEDS; CREATING A REPOSITORY OF RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO MEET THOSE NEEDS AND INCREASE THE USE OF THOSE RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML, 3) THE DHP WILL FACILITATE INCREASED AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND COMPETENCY OF HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS TO DELIVER ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTHCARE TO ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML, 4) THE DHP WILL FACILITATE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND APPROPRIATE LINKAGE OF CARE TO ADULTS WITH IDD WITH RECOMMENDED PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLE BEHAVIORS. SPECIFICALLY, WAYS TO ADDRESS BARRIERS TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE; LINKAGES TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND MENTAL HEALTH CARE; AND HEALTH PROMOTION ACTIVITIES, 5)THE DHP WILL FACILITATE INCREASED ENROLLMENT OF ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML IN EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTIONS. INCLUDING INCREASED ADOPTION OF HEALTHY BEHAVIORS AMONG THE TARGET POPULATION AND AN INCREASE IN NOTABLE POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES, AND 6) THE DHP WILL INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF BEST PRACTICES AND LESSONS LEARNED AND WILL SHARE THE INFORMATION WITH OTHER RECIPIENTS AND HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, AND POLICYMAKERS TO FACILITATE THEIR INCREASED KNOWLEDGE ABOUT WAYS TO PROMOTE HEALTH AMONG ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES.  THE STAFF OF THE DHP WILL UTILIZE THE RESULTS OF THE PROGRESS MONITORING OF THE SHORT-TERM AND INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES TO INFORM AND STRENGTHEN THE PROGRAM’S IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGIES TO BETTER ACCOMPLISH LONG-TERM HEALTH OUTCOMES. BECAUSE OF THE COMPLEXITY AND THE INCREASING NUMBERS OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES IN UTAH REQUIRING SERVICES, A NUMB

IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES THROUGH STATE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS IN MASSACHUSETTS - THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH (MDPH) OFFICE OF HEALTH EQUITY (OHE) IS SEEKING CDC FUNDING TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML) AND INTELLECTUAL DISABILITIES (IDD) IN MASSACHUSETTS. THIS WORK WILL LEVERAGE OHE?S HEALTH AND DISABILITY PROGRAM (HDP) INFRASTRUCTURE AND ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY. THROUGH COLLABORATIVE INITIATIVES WITH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL PARTNERS, INCLUDING MOUS WITH SISTER AGENCIES, HDP WILL (1) ESTABLISH, EXPAND, AND ENHANCE PARTNERSHIPS WITH ORGANIZATIONS THAT SERVE ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES, INCLUDING NACCHO AND NCHPAD; (2) CONDUCT COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENTS TO IDENTIFY GAPS IN RESOURCES AND TOOLS, AND IDENTIFY ACTION STEPS TO FILL THOSE GAPS IN MASSACHUSETTS; (3) ADMINISTER AND EVALUATE TRAININGS FOR PROVIDERS ON ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE; (4) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO LINK ADULTS WITH IDD TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS IN THEIR COMMUNITY; (5) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTIONS, AS WELL AS POLICY, SYSTEM AND ENVIRONMENTAL (PSE) CHANGES, AND DEVELOP RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO ADDRESS HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML; AND (6) DISSEMINATE KEY FINDINGS AND LESSONS LEARNED. LONG-TERM OUTCOMES AMONG THE TARGET POPULATIONS INCLUDE IMPROVEMENTS IN (1) NUMBER OF PROVIDERS THAT CAN OFFER ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE, (2) FEWER UNMET PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE NEEDS, INCLUDING MENTAL HEALTH; (3) HEALTH BEHAVIORS AND WELLNESS; (4) CHRONIC CONDITIONS AND RISK FACTORS. AS IN PREVIOUS CDC GRANT CYCLES, HDP WILL BE THE LEAD UNIT WITHIN MDPH FOR THIS WORK, PROVIDING FULL PROGRAMMATIC AND FISCAL OVERSIGHT. HDP WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO LEAD THE MASSACHUSETTS HEALTH AND DISABILITY PARTNERSHIP, A STATEWIDE ADVISORY COMMITTEE THAT INCLUDES MDPH PROGRAMS, SISTER AGENCIES, COMMUNITY-BASED SERVICE PROVIDERS, AND SELF-ADVOCATES TO ENSURE THAT ALL EFFORTS AND DECISIONS ARE STAKEHOLDER INFORMED AND CARRIE D OUT IN A COLLABORATIVE, EFFICIENT, EFFECTIVE, AND EQUITABLE MANNER TO ADDRESS DISPARITIES IMPACTING ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML. HDP WILL TRACK AND EVALUATE ALL PROGRAM ACTIVITIES TO REPORT ON PROGRESS AND OUTCOMES AND DISSEMINATE FINDINGS.

UMKC-IHD IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES - THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI-KANSAS CITY INSTITUTE FOR HUMAN DEVELOPMENT (UMKC-IHD) IS APPLYING TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION?S NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY FOR IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES THROUGH STATE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS. THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED MISSOURI DISABILITY AND HEALTH COLLABORATIVE IS TO INCREASE ACCESS TO AND USE OF PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION ACTIVITIES BY INDIVIDUALS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND/OR INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (IDD) ACROSS MISSOURI. WE WILL ACHIEVE THIS PURPOSE THROUGH A MULTIDISCIPLINARY COLLABORATION THAT WILL ASSESS NEEDS, TRAIN HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS IN ACCESSIBLE CARE METHODS, AND IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE INTERVENTIONS TO LINK INDIVIDUALS TO PREVENTIVE CARE AND INCREASE HEALTH AND WELLNESS BEHAVIORS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED CAPACITY AT THE STATE, COUNTY, LOCAL, AND ORGANIZATIONAL LEVELS TO PROVIDE ACCESSIBLE, HIGH-QUALITY PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION SERVICES TO PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES. KEY GRANT PARTNERS WILL INCLUDE THE MISSOURI BUREAU OF COMMUNITY HEALTH AND WELLNESS, MISSOURI CHRONIC DISEASE PROGRAM, COUNTY DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES SERVICES BOARDS, PEOPLE FIRST SELF-ADVOCACY ORGANIZATION, CENTERS FOR INDEPENDENT LIVING, MISSOURI STATEWIDE INDEPENDENT LIVING COUNCIL, SPECIAL OLYMPICS MISSOURI, MISSOURI PRIMARY CARE ASSOCIATION, MISSOURI STATE ALLIANCE OF YMCAS, CLINICAL HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS, LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH AGENCIES, AND THE MISSOURI ASSOCIATION OF REHABILITATION FACILITIES. PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS, PEOPLE WITH IDD, AND THEIR FAMILY MEMBERS WILL ALSO BE INVOLVED IN ALL ASPECTS OF PLANNING, LEADING, IMPLEMENTING, AND EVALUATING THE PROJECT. OBJECTIVES INCLUDE:1. ESTABLISH A STATEWIDE ADVISORY WORKGROUP THAT WILL EXPAND AND ENHANCE PARTNERSHIPS NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT AND SUSTAIN PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES.2.  CONDUCT NEEDS ASSESSMENTS T O IDENTIFY GAPS IN INFORMATION AND RESOURCES AND BARRIERS TO ENGAGEMENT WITH PREVENTIVE HEALTHCARE SERVICES AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS, AND IDENTIFY ACTION STEPS TO FILL GAPS3. ADMINISTER AND EVALUATE TRAINING FOR HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS ON ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE4. CONDUCT A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO LINK PEOPLE WITH IDD WHO HAVE UNMET PREVENTIVE CARE NEEDS WITH COMMUNITY HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION RESOURCES.5. IDENTIFY, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTIONS FOR ADULTS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND ADULTS WITH IDD. IDENTIFY, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES RELATED TO ACCESSIBLE HEALTH PROMOTION FOR THE TARGET AUDIENCES.6. DISSEMINATE PROJECT FINDINGS AND PRODUCTS TO DIVERSE AUDIENCES PROJECT LONG-TERM OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE INCREASED NUMBER OF PROVIDERS OFFERING ACCESSIBLE HEALTH CARE, FEWER UNMET PREVENTIVE CARE NEEDS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD, HEALTHIER BEHAVIORS AMONG ADULTS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND IDD, AND REDUCED PREVALENCE OF CHRONIC DISEASE AND RISK FACTORS IN THE TARGET POPULATIONS. SHORT- AND MEDIUM-TERM OUTCOMES FOCUS ON ENHANCED PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN THE PUBLIC HEALTH AND DISABILITY SECTORS, INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS BY PROVIDERS, INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS ABOUT PREVENTIVE CARE AMONG ADULTS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND ADULTS WITH IDD, INCREASED ENROLLMENT IN HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS, INCREASED STATE AND COMMUNITY USE OF RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF THE TARGET POPULATIONS, AND ADOPTION OF POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES BY COMMUNITIES AND ORGANIZATIONS.

IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES THROUGH STATE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS - THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THE NEW YORK STATE (NYS) DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (DOH) DISABILITY AND HEALTH PROGRAM (DHP) IS TO PROMOTE HEALTH AMONG PEOPLE WITH DISABILITY BY ADVANCING RECOGNITION AND UNDERSTANDING OF HEALTH DISPARITIES EXPERIENCED BY PEOPLE WITH DISABILITY, AND MOBILIZING PUBLIC HEALTH, HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS, PEOPLE WITH DISABILITY, AND COMMUNITIES TO RESPOND THROUGH IMPLEMENTATION OF EVIDENCE-BASED AND EVIDENCE INFORMED POLICES, PRACTICES AND INTERVENTIONS. PERSONS WITH DISABILITY ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY CHRONIC DISEASE AND RELATED RISK FACTORS. DATA FROM THE NYS BRFSS, 2018 REPORT NEW YORKERS (NYERS) WITH DISABILITY ARE MORE LIKELY THAN THOSE WITHOUT DISABILITY TO REPORT HAVING DIABETES (23% VS. 7%), ARTHRITIS (52% VS. 17%), CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE (20.5% VS. 5%) AND DEPRESSIVE DISORDERS (31.6% VS 9.6%). COMPARED TO THEIR PEERS WITHOUT DISABILITY, PERSONS WITH DISABILITY ARE AT HIGHER RISK OF HAVING OBESITY, ENGAGING IN LESS PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND USING TOBACCO. NEARLY 1 IN 5 OF ADULTS WITH DISABILITY REPORTED THAT THEY DID NOT HAVE A ROUTINE PHYSICAL EXAM WITHIN THE PAST YEAR AND OVER 40% REPORTED NOT HAVING A DENTAL EXAM WITHIN THE PAST YEAR. THESE HEALTH CARE ACCESS DISPARITIES CAN BE ADDRESSED IN A NUMBER OF WAYS INCLUDING COMPREHENSIVE MEDICAL CARE THAT INCLUDES WELL-EDUCATED PROVIDERS WHO UNDERSTAND THE NEEDS OF THIS POPULATION, AN OFFICE ENVIRONMENT THAT MEETS THE NEEDS OF THE PATIENT, AND ACCESS TO ALL TOOLS AND EQUIPMENT NEEDED TO PROVIDE QUALITY CARE FOR THIS DIVERSE POPULATION.THE AIM OF THE PROPOSAL IS TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS RELATED TO REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG NYERS WITH INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (IDD) AND MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML). THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH KEY ORGANIZATIONS AND IN COLLABORATION WITH OTHER AWARD RECIPIENTS, THE NYS DHP WILL CONDUCT A STATEWIDE COMMUNITY NEEDS ASSESSMENT TO IDENTIFY GAPS IN RESOURCES; OFFER TRAININGS FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS ON ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE CARE; AND  DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT, INCLUDING HIRING A LINKAGE COORDINATOR, TO LINK ADULTS WITH IDD TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS IN THEIR COMMUNITY. TO FURTHER ADDRESS HEALTH DISPARITIES IN BOTH POPULATIONS, POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES WILL BE IMPLEMENTED AND AN EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTION WILL BE ADMINISTERED. THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT PERIOD, KEY FINDINGS AND LESSONS LEARNED WILL BE DISSEMINATED STATEWIDE THROUGH VARIOUS COMMUNICATION CHANNELS.BY THE END OF THE 5-YEAR PROJECT PERIOD, THE DHP AIMS TO ACCOMPLISH MEASURABLE IMPROVEMENTS IN ADDRESSING HEALTH DISPARITIES SEEN IN OUR TARGET POPULATION; ADULTS WITH IDD AND ML. THIS INCLUDES INCREASING THE NUMBER OF PROVIDERS THAT CAN OFFER ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE; FEWER UNMET PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE NEEDS; INCREASING HEALTHY BEHAVIORS; A DECREASE IN CHRONIC CONDITIONS;  ADDRESSING BARRIERS RELATED TO MANAGING CHRONIC CONDITIONS AND MITIGATING RISK FACTORS.

MT DISABILITY AND HEALTH PROGRAM IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES & MOBILITY LIMITATIONS THROUGH STATE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYMONTANA (MT) HAS A RICH HISTORY OF INTEGRATING DISABILITY INTO PUBLIC HEALTH POLICY, SYSTEMS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL ACTIVITIES AND INTERVENTIONS. ACCORDINGLY, THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (DPHHS) IS PLEASED TO SUBMIT THIS PROPOSAL, IN RESPONSE TO THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION?S (CDC) FUNDING OPPORTUNITY, CDC-RFA-DD21-2103, IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES THROUGH STATE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS TO CONTINUE THE MONTANA DISABILITY AND HEALTH PROGRAM?S (MTDH).GEOGRAPHICALLY, MONTANA IS THE FOURTH LARGEST STATE BY LAND AREA, ENCOMPASSING 29% PUBLIC LANDS AND EIGHT TRIBAL NATIONS. A SIGNIFICANT PROPORTION OF MONTANA?S POPULATION EXPERIENCES RISKS THAT MAY LEAD TO CHRONIC DISEASE AND DISABILITY. BETWEEN 16.1% AND 30.7% OF MONTANA ADULTS REPORT HAVING AT LEAST ONE DISABILITY. OVERALL, 8.1-10.1% OF MONTANANS REPORT A MOBILITY IMPAIRMENT AND 5.4-10.7% REPORT A COGNITIVE DISABILITY. RECOGNIZING DISABILITY AS AN IMPORTANT PUBLIC HEALTH ISSUE, DPHHS ESTABLISHED THE MTDH PROGRAM IN 2002. ADMINISTRATIVELY LOCATED IN THE CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION BUREAU, MTDH EMPLOYS SUSTAINABLE, HIGH-IMPACT POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL ACTIVITIES AND INTERVENTIONS THROUGH A COMMUNITY PARTICIPATORY, MULTI-LEVEL, AND COORDINATED APPROACH. PROGRAMMATICALLY, MTDH IS EXECUTED THROUGH A CONTRACT WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA RURAL INSTITUTE FOR INCLUSIVE COMMUNITIES AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FROM CDC-FUNDED NATIONAL CENTER?S ON DISABILITY AND DISABILITY SERVICE AGENCIES. MTDH HAS BUILT A STATE-WIDE NETWORK THAT REACHES AND PROMOTES HEALTH AMONG ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITY (IDD), ADULTS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML), AND THEIR FAMILIES AND CAREGIVERS IN RURAL AREAS. MTDH HAS OPERATED EFFECTIVELY FOR NEARLY 20 YEARS AND HAS THE EXPERIENCE AND CAPACITY TO EXPAND AND SUSTAIN PARTNERSHIPS AND COLLABORATIVE ACT IONS NECESSARY TO SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENT THE GRANT ACTIVITIES AND ACHIEVE THE PROJECT OUTCOMES. SPECIFICALLY, MTDH PROPOSES TO IMPROVE HEALTHY LIFESTYLES BY: (1) INCREASING THE NUMBER OF HEALTH PROVIDERS ABLE TO OFFER ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTHCARE IN A RURAL STATE, (2) DECREASING UNMET PREVENTATIVE AND MENTAL HEALTHCARE NEEDS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND THEIR CAREGIVER, (3) IMPROVING HEALTHY BEHAVIORS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ML, AND (4) REDUCING PREVALENCE OF CHRONIC DISEASES, SECONDARY CONDITIONS, AND ASSOCIATED RISK FACTORS, INCLUDING BETTER MENTAL HEALTH. FINALLY, PERFORMANCE MONITORING FOR MTDH WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE MONTANA PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY DIVISION?S (PHSD) EXISTING PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THE PMS USES A WEB-BASED DATABASE TO MANAGE ALL WORK ACROSS PHSD WITH PROGRAM WORKPLANS USING A STANDARDIZED FORMAT THAT INCLUDES THE DESIRED STRATEGY OUTCOMES, ACTIVITIES/SUB-ACTIVITIES, PROCESS AND OUTCOME MEASURES AND BUDGET INFORMATION.

IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS AND INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL IN MICHIGAN - THE DISABILITY HEALTH PROGRAM (DHP) AT THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (MDHHS) HAS BEEN FUNDED BY THE CDC SINCE 2007 TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES (PWD), AND IMPROVE THE ACCESSIBILITY OF THE STATE?S PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS.DHP HAS BUILT AND SUSTAINED A COORDINATED PUBLIC HEALTH APPROACH TO IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PWD THROUGH STRONG DATA COLLECTION, IMPROVING ACCESS TO PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS, INSTITUTING POLICY CHANGE, EDUCATING HEALTHCARE AND PUBLIC HEALTH PROFESSIONALS IN ACCESS AND INCLUSION, AND IMPLEMENTING EVIDENCE BASED HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS. THIS PROPOSAL PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY TO EXPAND THESE EFFORTS USING THE FOLLOWING STRATEGIES.1. EXPAND PARTNERSHIPS. OUR EXISTING ADVISORY COUNCIL (AC) INCLUDES DISABILITY ADVOCACY AND SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS, PUBLIC HEALTH AND IMPLEMENTATION PARTNERS. WE WILL EXPAND MEMBERSHIP TO INCLUDE PARTNERS WHOSE WORK COMPLEMENTS THE STRATEGIES IN THIS APPLICATION, INCLUDING MORE PWD AND FAMILIES, HEALTH SYSTEMS, RECREATION AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS.2. CONDUCT NEEDS ASSESSMENTS. DHP WILL WORK WITH THE DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES INSTITUTE (DDI - OUR STATE?S UNIVERSITY CENTER OF EXCELLENCE IN DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITY) TO CONDUCT A STATEWIDE NEEDS ASSESSMENT FOR PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITY (IDD) AND THEIR FAMILIES, IDENTIFYING GAPS IN RESOURCES/SERVICES AND BARRIERS TO UTILIZATION, AND, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OUR AC, CREATE A PLAN TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS.3. TRAIN HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS. IN COLLABORATION WITH DDI AND OTHER GRANTEES, DHP WILL IDENTIFY EXISTING DISABILITY COMPETENCY TRAINING FOR HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS, AND USE THEIR EXTENSIVE PROVIDER NETWORKS TO RECRUIT PARTICIPANTS. DHP AND DDI STAFF WILL DELIVER THE SELECTED TRAININGS AND COLLECT DATA ON EFFECTIVENESS AND REACH.4. IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT; CREATE COMMUNITY RESOURCE DIRECTORIES. WORKING WITH DDI AND OTHER AWARDEES, DHP WILL IMPLEMENT A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO INCREASE HEALTHCARE SCREENING AND RATES OF PREVENTIVE CARE AMONG PEOPLE WITH IDD IN THE DETROIT METRO AREA (THE MOST POPULOUS AREA IN THE STATE, AND THE MOST AFFECTED BY DISABILITY AND HEALTH DISPARITIES), RECRUITING AND RETAINING AT LEAST 200 PEOPLE WITH IDD DURING THE FUNDING PERIOD. DHP WILL ALSO WORK WITH THE NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION OF MICHIGAN (NKFM) IN THE CREATION OF AN ACCESSIBLE, PLAIN-LANGUAGE GUIDE TO LOCATING AND ACCESSING RESOURCES FOR HEALTH AND SOCIAL NEEDS, STARTING WITH METRO DETROIT AND ADDING A NEW AREA OF THE STATE EACH GRANT YEAR.5. IMPLEMENT EVIDENCE BASED PROGRAMS (EBPS) AND POLICY/SYSTEMS CHANGE. DHP AND NKFM HAVE SIGNIFICANT EXPERIENCE IN ACCESSIBLY-DELIVERED EBPS FOR PEOPLE WITH IDD AND MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML). WE HAVE NETWORKS IN PLACE TO DELIVER A VARIETY OF HEALTH PROMOTION OR CHRONIC DISEASE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS: WALK WITH EASE (AN EDUCATIONAL WALKING PROGRAM FOR PEOPLE WITH ML); STANFORD?S CHRONIC DISEASE SELF-MANAGEMENT PROGRAM; ENHANCEFITNESS (AN INCLUSIVE EXERCISE PROGRAM FOR PWD AND OLDER ADULTS, INCLUDING THOSE WITH IDD); AND/OR THE DIABETES PREVENTION PROGRAM FOR PEOPLE WITH IDD. SHOULD THE GRANTEES SELECT A DIFFERENT EBP, THE DHP AND NKFM HAVE CAPACITY TO TRAIN INSTRUCTORS AND IMPLEMENT THE REQUESTED PROGRAM. DHP WILL EFFECT POLICY CHANGE BY TRAINING OUR BUREAU?S DIVERSITY HIRING TEAM IN ACCESSIBLE RECRUITING AND HIRING, ENSURING DISABILITY COMPETENCY ON ALL HIRING TEAMS; PARTNERING WITH THE  MICHIGAN PARKS ASSOCIATION TO SEEK CHANGES IN THE ACCESSIBILITY OF SELECT PARKS THROUGH THE INSTALLATION OF POWER WHEELCHAIR CHARGING STATIONS; AND WORKING WITH THE HEALTHY DEARBORN COALITION TO INCLUDE DISABILITY INITIATIVES IN COMMUNITY PROGRAMMING.6. DISSEMINATE KEY FINDINGS. DHP WILL COLLECT LESSONS LEARNED FROM THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES AND SHARE WITH PUBLIC HEALTH, HEALTHCARE, DISABILITY AND GOVERNMENT PARTNERS OVER THE LIFE OF THE GRANT.DHP WILL IMPLEMENT OUR EVAL

NEW HAMPSHIRE DISABILITY AND HEALTH PROGRAM - OVERVIEW. THE NEW HAMPSHIRE DISABILITY AND HEALTH PROGRAM (NH DHP) IMPROVES THE HEALTH AND QUALITY OF LIFE OF PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES IN NEW HAMPSHIRE BY IMPLEMENTING EVIDENCE-BASED STRATEGIES TO REDUCE UNMET HEALTH NEEDS, INCREASE ACCESS TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE, AND FACILITATE THE ADOPTION OF HEALTHY BEHAVIORS. PURPOSE. THE PURPOSE OF NH DHP IS TO ADDRESS HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (IDD) AND ADULTS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML). NH DHP WILL DRAW ON AND EXPAND STATEWIDE, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL PARTNERSHIPS TO IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE EVIDENCE-BASED STRATEGIES IN ORDER TO: A) ASSESS COMMUNITY NEEDS AND IDENTIFY ACTION STEPS TO FILL GAPS; B) TRAIN HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS ON THE PROVISION OF ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE; C) CONDUCT A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO LINK ADULTS WITH IDD TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES; D) SUPPORT INTERVENTIONS AND DEVELOP NEEDED RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO PROMOTE POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES; AND E) DISSEMINATE KEY FINDINGS AND SHARE LESSONS LEARNED.OUTCOMES. BY THE END OF THE FIVE-YEAR PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE, NH DPH WILL RESULT IN: ?INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF NEEDS WITHIN THE STATE, A REPOSITORY OF RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO MEET THOSE NEEDS, AND  INCREASED USE OF RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML; ?INCREASED DISABILITY-COMPETENCE AND IMPROVED EFFORTS AMONG HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS TO DELIVER ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE;?INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD ABOUT RECOMMENDED PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE, HEALTHY LIFESTYLE BEHAVIORS, AND WAYS TO ADDRESS BARRIERS TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE;?IMPROVED LINKAGES WITH PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE, MENTAL HEALTH CARE, AND HEALTH PROMOTION ACTIVITIES AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD;?INCREASED PARTICIPATION IN EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTIONS AND INCREASED ADOPTION OF HEALTHY BEHAVIORS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML;?IMPROVEMENT S TO POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES WITHIN THE STATE;?IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF BEST PRACTICES AND LESSONS LEARNED THROUGH THE 10 STATE-BASED PROGRAMS; AND?INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AMONG HEALTH PROFESSIONALS AND POLICYMAKERS ABOUT WAYS TO PROMOTE THE HEALTH OF ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES.COLLABORATION. NH DHP IS GUIDED AND ASSISTED BY AN ADVISORY WORKGROUP COMPRISED OF EXPERTS IN THE FIELDS OF PUBLIC HEALTH, HEALTH CARE, AND DISABILITY, INCLUDING SELF-ADVOCATES WITH IDD, SELF-ADVOCATES WITH ML, FAMILY MEMBERS AND CAREGIVERS. STATEWIDE AND REGIONAL PARTNERS PROVIDE INPUT ABOUT THE BEST METHODS TO ACHIEVE PROJECT OUTCOMES AND SUPPORT PROJECT EFFORTS BY LEVERAGING RESOURCES AND NETWORKS WITHIN THE STATE. NH DHP COLLABORATES WITH OTHER STATE AWARDEES, CDC, AND THE NATIONAL CENTERS ON DISABILITY TO ACHIEVE COMMON GOALS, INCREASE PROGRAM REACH, AND ENHANCE PROGRAM IMPACTS.

IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL/DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES AND MOBILITY LIMITATIONS IN GEORGIA - NEARLY 28% OF ADULTS LIVING IN GEORGIA HAVE SOME TYPE OF DISABILITY. GEORGIANS WITH INTELLECTUAL ANDDEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (IDD) AND THOSE WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML) EXPERIENCE PROFOUND HEALTHDISPARITIES COMPARED TO ADULTS WITHOUT DISABILITIES. THEY ARE MORE LIKELY TO REPORT HAVING POOR OR FAIR HEALTH,EXPERIENCE A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN OF PREVENTABLE CHRONIC CONDITIONS, AND REPORT SIGNIFICANTLY MOREMENTALLY UNHEALTHY DAYS COMPARED TO ADULTS WITHOUT DISABILITIES. THESE DISPARITIES ARE INFLUENCED BY ANUMBER OF POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, INCLUDING LACK OF ACCESS TO ADEQUATELY TRAINEDHEALTHCARE PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL BARRIERS TO RECEIVING CARE. DESPITE INCREASING EFFORTS TO ADDRESS DISABILITYHEALTH DISPARITIES AT THE NATIONAL LEVEL, COORDINATED AND CONTEXT-SPECIFIC EFFORTS TO REDUCE HEALTHINEQUITIES FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES LIVING IN GEORGIA HAVE NOT BEEN REALIZED.IN THIS APPLICATION, THE CENTER FOR LEADERSHIP IN DISABILITY AT GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY DESCRIBES ACOMPREHENSIVE PLAN TO REDUCE HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML INGEORGIA. THROUGH A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION, NATIONALCENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, WE PROPOSE TO:1) ESTABLISH, EXPAND, AND ENHANCE PARTNERSHIPS WITH STATEWIDE AND NATIONAL PARTNERS;2) CONDUCT NEEDS ASSESSMENTS TO IDENTIFY GAPS IN ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTHPROMOTION SERVICES AVAILABLE TO ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML;3) ADMINISTER AND EVALUATE A TRAINING FOR HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS ON ACCESSIBLE HEALTH CARE;4) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO LINK ADULTS WITH IDD TO ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVEHEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES;5) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTIONS AND POLICY, SYSTEMS, ANDENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES; AND6) DISSEMINATE KEY FINDINGS AND LESSONS LEARNED.SEVERAL OF THE STRATEGIES DESCRIBED ABOVE WILL B E DESIGNED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OTHER STATE DISABILITY ANDHEALTH PROGRAMS AND IMPLEMENTED WITH A NUMBER OF GEORGIA COLLABORATORS. WE WILL SCALE THESE STRATEGIESAND ACTIVITIES STATEWIDE USING A PHASED IMPLEMENTATION APPROACH TO FACILITATE CONTINUOUS PROGRAMQUALITY IMPROVEMENT AND SUPPORT PROGRAM SUSTAINABILITY.EXPECTED OUTCOMES TO BE ACHIEVED DURING THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE INCLUDE STRENGTHENEDENGAGEMENT WITH STATE AND NATIONAL PARTNERS; INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF DISPARITIES AND NEEDS AT THESTATEWIDE AND HEALTH DISTRICT LEVELS; INCREASED COMPETENCY AMONG HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS TO SERVE ADULTS WITHIDD AND ADULTS WITH ML; INCREASED KNOWLEDGE AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD ABOUT PREVENTIVE HEALTHCARE ANDHEALTH BEHAVIORS, AND BARRIERS TO RECEIVING HEALTH CARE AND ENGAGING IN HEALTH BEHAVIORS; INCREASEDENGAGEMENT IN HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML; INCREASED POLICY,SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES IMPLEMENTED AT THE STATE AND HEALTH DISTRICT LEVELS; AND INCREASEDKNOWLEDGE AMONG HEALTH PROFESSIONALS AND POLICYMAKERS ABOUT WAYS TO IMPROVE DISABILITY HEALTH EQUITY.BEYOND THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE, IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING OUR PROPOSED PLAN WILL RESULT IN ANINCREASED NUMBER OF PROVIDERS THAT CAN OFFER ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE, AND FEWER UNMETPREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE NEEDS, IMPROVED HEALTH BEHAVIORS, AND REDUCED PREVALENCE OF CHRONIC CONDITIONSAND RISK FACTORS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML IN OUR STATE. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTETOWARD ADVANCING HEALTH EQUITY FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES IN GEORGIA AND THROUGHOUT THE NATION.

OREGON OFFICE ON DISABILITY AND HEALTH - THE OREGON OFFICE ON DISABILITY AND HEALTH (OODH) HAS BEEN CONTINUOUSLY FUNDED BY A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) SINCE 1994. WE ARE A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN OREGON HEALTH & SCIENCE UNIVERSITY AND THE OREGON HEALTH AUTHORITY, PUBLIC HEALTH DIVISION. OODH PROPOSES ACTIVITIES FOR THE NEXT FIVE YEARS TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION FOR ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (IDD) AND ADULTS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML) IN OREGON, WITH THE OVERARCHING LONG-TERM GOAL OF REDUCING HEALTH DISPARITIES IMPACTING THESE POPULATIONS. OODH WILL BUILD ON EXISTING STRENGTHS FROM OUR EXPERIENCE OVER THE LAST 27 YEARS. WE WILL CONTINUE TO WORK CLOSELY WITH THE PUBLIC HEALTH DIVISION OF THE OREGON HEALTH AUTHORITY, THE UNIVERSITY CENTER FOR EXCELLENCE IN DEVELOPMENT DISABILITIES AT OHSU, OUR DIVERSE AND KNOWLEDGEABLE ADVISORY COMMITTEE, AS WELL AS KEY DISABILITY ADVOCACY ORGANIZATIONS, DISABILITY SERVICES SYSTEMS, HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS, AND LOCAL AND COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS. THE KEY ACTIVITIES FOR OODH'S PROPOSED NEW CYCLE OF FUNDING ARE: (1) ESTABLISH, EXPAND, AND ENHANCE PARTNERSHIPS WITH ORGANIZATIONS THAT SERVE ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES; (2) CONDUCT STATEWIDE NEEDS ASSESSMENTS TO DESCRIBE HEALTH AND HEALTH CARE DISPARITIES AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML, IDENTIFY BARRIERS TO HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION, AND IDENTIFY ACTION STEPS TO ADDRESS BARRIERS AND GAPS; (3) ADMINISTER AND EVALUATE A TRAINING FOR HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS ON ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE; (4) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE A DEMONSTRATION PROJECT TO LINK ADULTS WITH IDD TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE AND HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS IN THEIR COMMUNITY; (5) IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION INTERVENTIONS, AS WELL AS POLICY, SYSTEM AND ENVIRONMENTAL (PSE) CHANGES, AND DEVELOP RESOURCES AND TOOLS TO ADDRESS HEALTH DISPARITIES AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND M L; AND (6) DISSEMINATE KEY FINDINGS AND LESSONS LEARNED. INTENDED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES INCLUDE: (1) INCREASED NUMBER OF PROVIDERS THAT CAN OFFER ACCESSIBLE PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE, (2) FEWER UNMET NEEDS FOR PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE, INCLUDING MENTAL HEALTH CARE, AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD; (3) INCREASED HEALTH BEHAVIORS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML IN OREGON; AND (4) REDUCED PREVALENCE OF CHRONIC DISEASES AND THEIR RISK FACTORS AMONG ADULTS WITH IDD AND ADULTS WITH ML IN OREGON.KEY PARTNERS FOR THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE OREGON RURAL PRACTICE-BASED RESEARCH NETWORK, THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES' OFFICE OF DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES SERVICES, OREGON 211INFO, THE NORTHWEST ADA CENTER, CAPETTY CONSULTING, HASL CENTER FOR INDEPENDENT LIVING, UMPQUA VALLEY DISABILITIES NETWORK, AND SPECIAL OLYMPICS OF OREGON. ADDITIONAL COLLABORATING AGENCIES THAT SUPPORT THIS WORK INCLUDE THE HEALTH PROMOTION AND CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION SECTION OF THE OREGON HEALTH AUTHORITY, THE OREGON STATE INDEPENDENT LIVING COUNCIL, THE OREGON OFFICE OF RURAL HEALTH AND THE FIVE REGIONAL AREA HEALTH EDUCATION CENTERS, THE OREGON WELLNESS CENTER, SPECIAL OLYMPICS NORTH AMERICA, AND THE NATIONAL CENTER ON HEALTH, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND DISABILITY. OODH STAFF HAVE THE NECESSARY SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE TO CONDUCT AND RIGOROUSLY EVALUATE ALL OF THE ABOVE ACTIVITIES. OUR POSITION WITHIN OREGON'S LARGEST ACADEMIC HEALTH CENTER AND OUR LONG-STANDING RELATIONSHIPS WITH DISABILITY ORGANIZATIONS AND PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS THROUGHOUT THE STATE PROVIDE US WITH THE RESOURCES AND CONNECTIONS NEEDED TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN ACHIEVING THE INTENDED OUTCOMES.

NATIONAL CENTER ON HEALTH, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND DISABILITY - THE HEALTHCARE SYSTEM AND PUBLIC HEALTH COMMUNITY ARE OFTEN UNDERPREPARED TO SUPPORT THE NEEDS OF INDIVIDUALS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS (ML) AND TO INCLUDE THEM EQUITABLY IN WELLNESS PROGRAMS (E.G., EXERCISE, LEISURE, NUTRITION, STRESS MANAGEMENT) OFFERED TO THE GENERAL COMMUNITY. CONSEQUENTLY, THE VAST MAJORITY OF PEOPLE WITH ML ARE UNABLE TO MAKE THE TRANSITION FROM ?PATIENT? TO ?PARTICIPANT,? WHICH CONTRIBUTES TO MANY OF THE HEALTH DISPARITIES SEEN IN THIS POPULATION. IN THIS FIVE-YEAR APPLICATION, THE NATIONAL CENTER ON HEALTH, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND DISABILITY (NCHPAD) WILL REDUCE THESE DISPARITIES BY PROVIDING AN EVIDENCE-BASED PATHWAY FROM HEALTHCARE TO WELLNESS FOR PEOPLE WITH ML. NCHPAD WILL ENGAGE THE SPECTRUM OF STAKEHOLDERS ? INDIVIDUALS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS, CAREGIVERS, HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, STUDENTS ? IN ORDER TO DELIVER ADAPTED PROGRAMS IN HEALTH PROMOTION AND WELLNESS THAT MEET THE UNIQUE NEEDS OF PEOPLE WITH ML AND HELP BRIDGE THIS GAP IN THE HEALTHCARE SYSTEM. ACTIVITIES FUNDED UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BE OFFERED BOTH IN HOME (THROUGH TELEHEALTH) AND IN COMMUNITY SETTINGS VIA THREE INTEGRATIVE STRATEGIES: 1) EXPAND CAPACITY FOR HEALTH SCREENING OF PEOPLE WITH ML AND ANALYZE HEALTH SCREENING DATA TO INFORM HEALTH AND WELLNESS PROGRAMS; 2) IMPLEMENT, EVALUATE, AND DISSEMINATE HEALTH PROMOTION/WELLNESS PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES THAT PROMOTE HEALTHY LIFESTYLE BEHAVIORS; AND 3) EXPAND CAPACITY THROUGH TRAINING HEALTHCARE AND COMMUNITY-BASED PROVIDERS TO REACH A GROWING NUMBER OF PEOPLE WITH ML WHO NEED ACCESS TO HEALTH PROMOTION/WELLNESS. BY EXPANDING ACCESS TO HEALTH AND WELLNESS PROGRAMS THAT ARE UNIQUELY ADAPTED TO THE NEEDS OF PEOPLE WITH ML, NCHPAD WILL BE THE CONDUIT THAT REDUCES THIS GAP IN HEALTHCARE AND PUBLIC HEALTH, INCREASING EQUITABILITY OF CARE AND IMPROVING QUALITY OF LIFE FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH MOBILITY LIMITATIONS.

IMPROVING HEALTH OF AMERICANS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISBAILITIES THROUGH EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS - FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: CDC-RFA-DD21-2102  CFDA(S): 93.184 -- DISABILITIES PREVENTION   APPLICANT NAME: SPECIAL OLYMPICS, INC.   DESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF APPLICANT?S PROJECT: SPECIAL OLYMPICS: A PATH TO IMPROVING HEALTH OF AMERICANS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES  PROJECT ABSTRACT: SPECIAL OLYMPICS WILL ADDRESS THE HEALTH DISPARITIES EXPERIENCED BY CHILDREN AND ADULTS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (IDD) THROUGH EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS AND INTERVENTIONS. THE PROJECT WILL UTILIZE THE WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION?S PRINCIPLES OF ACTION TO: (1) IMPROVE THE CONDITIONS OF DAILY LIFE BY ENCOURAGING COMMUNITIES TO BE ACCESSIBLE TO ALL; (2) TACKLE THE INEQUITABLE DISTRIBUTION OF RESOURCES BY INCREASING APPROPRIATE HEALTHCARE, SOCIAL PARTICIPATION, AND ACCESS TO NEEDED TECHNOLOGIES; AND (3) MEASURE THE PROBLEM, EVALUATE ACTION, EXPAND THE KNOWLEDGE BASE, DEVELOP A WORKFORCE THAT IS TRAINED, AND RAISE PUBLIC AWARENESS ABOUT THE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH. BUILDING ON TWO DECADES OF COLLABORATION WITH THE CDC?S NATIONAL CENTER ON BIRTH DEFECTS AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, SPECIAL OLYMPICS WILL EXPAND, MODERNIZE THROUGH TECHNOLOGY, AND STANDARDIZE ITS HEALTHY ATHLETES? AND HEALTHY COMMUNITIES PROGRAMS NATIONALLY THROUGH EVIDENCE-BASED INTERVENTIONS.SPECIAL OLYMPICS WILL CONDUCT THIS WORK BY FOCUSING ON THREE STRATEGIES AND FOUR ACTIVITIES. STRATEGIES INCLUDE: (1) HEALTH SCREENING AND REFERRAL TO APPROPRIATE CARE, TO INCREASE PERSON-CENTERED LINKAGES TO HEALTH SERVICES, INCLUDING ORAL AND MENTAL HEALTH CARE, VACCINATIONS, HEALTH CHECK-UPS, WOMEN?S HEALTH AND IMPROVED MANAGEMENT OF HEALTH CONDITIONS INCLUDING DIABETES, OBESITY, HEART DISEASE, HYPERTENSION, DEPRESSION, AND ANXIETY; (2) HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS TO INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF PERSONAL RISK FACTORS AND ADOPTION OF HEALTHY LIFESTYLE BEHAVIORS, INCREASE CONTROL OF CHRONIC CONDITIONS, AND IMPROVE LIFE SATISFACTION AND SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL SUPPORT; AND ( 3) BUILDING CAPACITY AMONG HEALTH PROFESSIONALS, STUDENTS, AND ORGANIZATIONS SO THAT THEY CAN DELIVER HIGH QUALITY INCLUSIVE HEALTH CARE, HEALTH PROGRAMS AND SERVICES TO PEOPLE WITH IDD.ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) PREVENTION OF CHRONIC CONDITIONS THROUGH ENGAGING, EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH PROGRAMMING LEADING TO REDUCTION IN PERSONAL RISK FACTORS AND (2) ASSESSMENT OF HEALTH THROUGH TECHNOLOGICALLY-ADVANCED SCREENINGS AND CARE COORDINATION LEADING TO IMPROVED EARLY DETECTION AND MANAGEMENT OF HEALTH CONDITIONS. (3) TRAINING OF THE HEALTHCARE WORKFORCE THROUGH COMPETENCY-BASED INTERPROFESSIONAL EDUCATIONAL CURRICULUM AND HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES WITH SPECIAL OLYMPICS ATHLETES AS CO-EDUCATORS LEADING TO IMPROVEMENTS IN COMPETENT COMPASSIONATE CARE (4) HEALTH SYSTEMS CHANGE THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS, CO-EDUCATION AND DATA SHARING LEADING TO INCLUSION OF PEOPLE WITH IDD IN POLICIES AND PRACTICES OF MAINSTREAM HEALTH ORGANIZATIONS. ENHANCED DATA COLLECTION SYSTEMS AND ONGOING DATA ANALYSIS WILL RESULT IN CONTINUOUS QUALITY IMPROVEMENT OF PROGRAMMING AND THE CREATION OF COMPELLING EVIDENCE THAT CAN BE USED FOR ADVOCACY TOWARDS SYSTEMIC CHANGE. THIS WORK WILL BE ENHANCED THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH THE NATIONAL CENTER ON HEALTH, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND DISABILITY (NCHPAD) AND LOCAL, STATE, AND TERRITORIAL HEALTH AGENCIES, AS WELL AS OTHER NATIONAL AND LOCAL PARTNERS IN THE COMMUNITY.AT THE END OF FIVE YEARS: ?200,000 CHILDREN WILL BE ENGAGED IN YOUNG ATHLETES EARLY INTERVENTION PROGRAMS, MAKING DEVELOPMENTAL AND HEALTH GAINS;?250,000 ATHLETES AND FAMILIES WILL BE ENGAGED IN HEALTHY LIFESTYLE AND FITNESS INTERVENTIONS WITH BEHAVIOR CHANGE TO PROMOTE REDUCTIONS IN CARDIOVASCULAR RISK; ?200,000 SCREENINGS WITH FOLLOW-UP WILL RESULT IN REDUCTIONS OF CHRONIC DISEASE MARKERS;?75 HEALTH PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS (INCLUDING MEDICAL, NURSING, PHYSICAL THERAPY AND/OR OTHERS) WILL INCLUDE CURRICULA ON
